name: Saw Palmetto
summary: Saw palmetto (Serenoa repens) is a herbal supplement commonly used for urinary and prostate health, particularly in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
description: Saw palmetto is derived from the berries of the Serenoa repens palm tree, native to the southeastern United States. It has traditionally been used to support urinary tract and reproductive health in men. The extract is thought to work by inhibiting 5-alpha-reductase, an enzyme that converts testosterone into dihydrotestosterone (DHT), which plays a role in prostate growth. While saw palmetto is widely used for symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), clinical trial evidence is mixed. Some studies suggest modest benefit in reducing urinary frequency, urgency, and nocturia, while others show minimal effects compared to placebo. It is generally well tolerated and is also marketed for hair loss, though evidence remains limited.

metadata.natural_source: Berries of Serenoa repens (saw palmetto palm)
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for BPH or other indications)

primary_indications: Support for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) symptoms
Urinary frequency and urgency in men
contraindications: Use with caution in patients taking anticoagulants or antiplatelet medications
Avoid in individuals with hormone-sensitive cancers unless supervised
monitoring_required: PSA (prostate-specific antigen) levels if used in prostate health context

items: May reduce urinary symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)
Supports prostate and urinary tract health
Sometimes used for hair loss prevention

sections.text: Saw palmetto extract is believed to inhibit the enzyme 5-alpha-reductase, reducing conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT). This may slow prostate growth and lower androgen-driven effects such as hair loss. It also has mild anti-inflammatory and anti-androgenic effects.

adult.typical: 160 mg twice daily of standardized extract (85–95% fatty acids and sterols)
adult.note: Consistency of extract quality is important for efficacy.

sections.text: Potential benefits on urinary symptoms may take several weeks to months; effects on hair loss are less predictable and may require prolonged use.

serious: Rare reports of liver or pancreas toxicity

other: May increase risk of bleeding if combined with anticoagulants or antiplatelets.
Not recommended in women who are pregnant or breastfeeding.
May lower PSA levels, potentially masking prostate disease progression.

items: Signs of bleeding if on anticoagulants

sections.pregnancy: Avoid; may interfere with hormone activity
sections.geriatrics: Generally well tolerated; monitor for efficacy and interactions

sections.text: No tapering required; supplementation can be discontinued without withdrawal.

items: Saw palmetto is one of the most widely used herbal treatments for BPH worldwide.
Clinical trials show mixed efficacy, with some finding results similar to placebo.
Standardized extracts are more reliable than whole berry powders.
